title: An Alternative To Standardized Tests Gets Green Light In N.H.
teaser: Four school districts have received federal approval to conduct a first-of-its-kind pilot program that will cut standardized testing in half.
contentencoded:
All across the country this spring, students will have to take a new set of standardized tests, aligned to the Common Core State Standards. Early indications are the test will be significantly more difficult than many statesâ€™ current tests, and teachers and administrators are anxious.

But in New Hampshire, four school districts have received federal approval to conduct a first-of-its-kind pilot program, which will mean cutting in half the number of times students take the statewide test, from seven to three.

From the Here & Now Contributors Network, Sam Evans-Brown of New Hampshire Public Radio reports that instead, the schools will give students assessments written by local teachers.
